The Board of Trustees, at a recent meeting, gave their approval
and support to the appeal of the
Library Committee to present the
library of the University of Louvain with a handsome set of serial
publications.
The University of Louvain suffered considerably at the hands of
the Hun invaders. The buildings
were set on fire and then allowed
to burn before the eyes of the i
habitants. The library was totally destroyed. Louvain will never
recover from the effects of wanton destruction, but something is
being done for it, both in the
United States and in England.
The movement which is afoot
here is being directed by Dr.
Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University. The
National Committee of the United
States for the Restoration of the
Louvain Library will collect the
mass of books that are offered by
the numerous colleges and univerThese
s lies of this country.
books, combined with those donated by England, will form the
nucleus of the library of the University of Louvain. The books
from both countries will be catalogued and presented together.
The splendid collection to be
presented by Johns Hopkins is
made up of over two hundred volumes of serial publications that
have been bound. Among these
are the American Chemical Journal, the American Journal of
Mathematics, the American Journal of Philology, Modern Language Notes and Studies of Historical and Political Science. Besides these, the Library Committee will endeavor to influence the
faculty to present some of their
own works.
After the nucleus of the Louvain library is formed, the list of
gifts given by the universities will
be used as a basis of appeal to
the general public to do its share
also.
The Library Committee, as it is
now composed, consists of President Frank Goodnow, chairman,
ex officio; Dr. Llewellyn Raney,
secretary, ex officio; Professors E.
B. Mathews, W. W. Willoughby,
J. S. Ames and W. P. Mustard.
Doctors Ames and Mustard were
recently appointed to fill the vacancies made by Prof. E. C. Armstrong, who is now at Princeton,
and by the late Prof. K. F. Smith.

The second of the Y. M. C. A.'s
series of lectures given with the
idea of helping undergraduates to
choose their life work was delivered by Mr. Eugene Levering, at
the lunch hour on Tuesday, March
4. Mr. Levering is the president
of the National Bank of Commerce
of Baltimore and one of the trustees of the University.
After speaking of the formation
of the world's first bank in Italy,
some time during the twelfth century, and of the gradual spreading of the institutions up through
Holland to England and over Europe, Mr. Levering spoke of the
three important kinds of banks
that were finally evolved and that
are at present in use. These three
kinds are: the savings bank, the
trust company and the commercial
bank.
The first savings bank was
formed about a hundred years ago
by a group of men who saw the
need of a bank especially adapted
to encourage the habit of saving.
The savings bank's great functions
are to help men by helping them
to save money and to supply long
term capital to business. The trust
company's major function, Mr.
Levering stated, is to develop industrial enterprises, such as the
railroads.
The commercial banks are divided into two classes: the national bank and the state bank.
There are many more state banks
than national banks; indeed, the
ratio is almost two to one. The
state banks are almost as well
managed now as the national
banks. This is brought about by
a method of state inspection corresponding to the Government inspection of national banks. The
function of the commercial bank
is seen when we consider the wonderful benefit the banks bestow on
business. A merchant, for instance, receives checks from all
parts of the country. Does he
send men around to all the banks
upon which the checks are drawn
to collect his money? Not at all.
What he does is simply to send all
his checks to his own bank, which
credits him with their amounts.
Then his bank, through the clearing-house, sends all the checks to
their proper banks. But the greatest benefit commercial banks bestow on business is to supply
short-term capital.

President Goodnow and Dr. W.
W. Willoughby, professor of political science at the University,
will soon go to Poland to draw
up a constitution for it, to organize its government and to start it
operating on a more modern basis. Associated with them in this
reconstruction work will be Samuel Gompers, of the American
Federation of Labor, who is now
abroad; Oscar S. Straus, of New
York, former United States Ambassador to Turkey; and Jeremiah
Jenks, a well-known political
economist.
Dr. Goodnow has been appointed chairman and Dr. Willoughby
secretary of the commission. The
National Civic Federation, which
had been asked by the leaders of
Poland to select a commission for
the formation of a new government, appointed the delegates. It..
is understood that the names of
these men were submitted to Ignace Jan Paderewski, President
of Poland, and his associates, and
that they unanimously approved
them.
Dr. Goodnow is at the present
time interested in getting the University running smoothly again
and in making the readjustments
that are necessary after the
changes inflicted by the war,
which caused considerable deliberation before accepting the appointment. Dr. Willoughby returned to Baltimore only a short
time ago after a year spent in
China as a constitutional advisor
to the Chinese Republic, a position
in which Dr. Goodnow had pre.
ceded him, and in which Dr. Goodnow spent several years before becoming President of the Johns
Hopkins.
The commission will leave in the
next few weeks, and Dr. Goodnow
and Dr. Willoughby will, in all
likelihood, not return before the
end of the scholastic year.

The second of the Aldred Lectures on "The Human Element in
the Machine Shop," was given by
Mr. James Hartness last Wednesday evening, before the Engineering Department faculty and students, and visitors. Besides being an inventor of note, Mr. Hartness has been president of the
American Society of Mechanical
Engineers, and was spokesman for
a delegation to Europe from that
society in 1913.
He stated that the human element is being obscured by the
specialization that is coming more
and more into our industries. The
two great divisions, mental and
manual, the executives and the
workingmen, must know each
other, co-operate with each other,
and promote a fellowship in viewpoint.
Specialization, Mr. Harkness
pointed out, does not lead away
from democracy. Anarchy results when men fall away from
specialization and co-operation.
Many of the past failures of our
nation were due to -the overlooking of this fact. This war was
won by an industrial strength
that backed up the armies. There
should be no antagonism to specialization because of its misuse
in Prussia; there it was used for
the benefit of the inner few.
It is the task of the young engineers, said the speaker, to fit
themselves for the positions which
they can best fill. One characteristic, observed in all of the leaders of industry, is a close understanding of their fellow creatures.
A great stumbling block to
many students is the theory that
a short, intensive course will fit
one for almost any position. Theoretical knowledge must be accompanied by practical experience. Likewise, interest in, and

Inter-collegiate Debate May 3rd.

The triangular debate between
Virginia, North Carolina and
Hopkins will be held May 3. The
question to be debated will be the
same as that which formed the
subject of the recent Adams Debate: "Resolved, that the Federal
Government of the United States
should own and operate the railroads." It has been seen in the
inter-class debate that this question of Government ownership is
a very interesting one, offering
plenty of opportunity for the display of debating talent.
According to the present arrangement, two teams from each
university will go away to debate,
and Virginia and North Carolina
will contest here in our Civil Engineering Building at Homewood.
The Debating Council of Johns
Hopkins, however, has proposed a
change this year, suggesting that
only one team should debate away,
keeping the other team to debate
on home ground.
Tryouts for the University
teams will be conducted by Dr.
French on Tuesday, March 11.

The Johns Hopkins Dramatic.
Club will produce "You Never

Work on the play is progressing favorably. Miss Walter, the

footgear, thereby developing the

As college activities are almost
restored to a pre-war basis, the
University of Pennsylvania has announced that it will hold its relay carnival as in previous years.
It will take place April 25 and 26
at Franklin Field, Philadelphia.
Invitations have been sent to all
the colleges of the country and
to the larger preparatory schools
to send relay teams to compete for
the prizes which will be awarded.

There is a yarn afoot among.
the students about a little incident that took place a couple of
Sundays ago, when Secretary of
War Newton D. Baker attended
the memorial meeting for the late
Prof. Kirby Flower Smith. It
goes that Mr. Baker came up the
road by the Mechanical Engineering Building with a bunch of papers under his arm and inquired
of one of the junior engineers the
way to the Civil Engineering
Building. The junior gave the information and then turned to
George, the Gilman Hall janitor,
and said: "Say, George, didn't
you know who that was? That's
Secretary of War Baker."
George immediately hot-footed
it up the road after Mr. Baker,
and said: "Mr. Baker, are you the
Secretary of War?" The visitor
replied that he was; then George
offered to show him around Gilman Hall. The secretary being
a little early, acquiesced, and inspected the building. A little
later one of the students ran
across George on the quadrangle
and asked him "how about it?"
George replied: "I'll be hanged!
I thought that bird was good for
at least one bone, and he never
even give me a durned cent!"

Harvard admitted freshmen
during January without examinations who before entering the
service completed a school record
which created the reasonable presumption that they would have
passed entrance examinations at
the natural period had they not
entered the service. They will
be registered as unclassified students their ultimate classification to depend on their first year's
record. Harvard will conduct a
twelve weeks' summer session this
year instead of the usual six
weeks' one, to enable these men to
do a full year's work between
January and September and thus
reach sophomore standing in the
fall.

"Tiff" Williams Elected Toastmaster

A meeting of the senior class
was held on Thursday, March 6,
in the Mechanical Engineering
Building to discuss several important matters relating to the welfare of the class. In the first
place, there was the matter of
electing a toastmaster for the senior banquet, which will take place
some time next month. The earsplitting roar which greeted the
nomination of "Tiff" Williams
for this position showed, beyond
a doubt, that no other candidate
would have a chance against him;
and the recognized "funny man"
of the class was elected by acclamation. This hilarious• demonstration was but short-lived, however, for the announcement which
immediately followed — that the
four-dollar pledges for the banquet would have to be signed then
and there—cast a gloomy silence
over the whole class. But the
thought of the approaching "dry
season" would have soon reconciled most of the men to any expenditure for the joys of a single
convivial evening, had not President Chisholm added insult to injury by saying that a collection
would have to be made to pay dues
to the Student Council and for
various other matters. There was
a large crowd present, but unfortunately the treasurer was absent, and so lost a good chance
of getting the money.
Thomsen announced that the
Hullabaloo is coming on splendidly, and from present indications
will be a year-book worthy of the
class. He urged all men who have
not yet done so to turn in their
biographies.

Boxing And Wrestling Classes Started.

Wrestling and boxing classes at
Hopkins have brought out material which will well be able to represent the University in the intercollegiate meets. These two new
„sports have but recently been
started under the new plan for
universal athletic participation by
the undergraduate students.
The wrestling teams especially
are now considered among the
most important athletic groups in
the eastern colleges. Annual winter schedules with final championship bouts have brought the
sport of the mat to the foreground
in college athletics. Although boxing and wrestling have not sought
recognition as minor sports, yet
it is expected that if Hopkins can
develop teams which hold their
own in the collegiate leagues, the
Athletic Board will give its approval.
Instruction in these two sports
is compulsory for the Sophomores,
and classes are open for all other
men interested. G. Wagner and
J. Marcuse are the boxing instructors, while A. Hendricks and
T. Gould coach the men on the
various holds in wrestling.
The classes meet for instruction on the fourth floor of Gilman
Hall, where large floor space offers room for several mats and
rings. Showers on the same floor
are used by the men. It is expected that as soon as a few men
get into shape, exhibitions will be
held at noon, and even public
bouts may be given.
While the weather prevents the
opening of the spring football
practice, Coach Murphy is urging
the candidates to get into shape
by practice on the canvas or with
the gloves. Experience as athletic director in the army camps
has convinced the coach that
these two sports are among the
best ways to get hardened and
• into shape for the fall workouts.

The Board of Trustees, at a recent meeting, gave their approval

The University of Louvain suffered considerably at the hands of
the Hun invaders. The buildings
were set on fire and then allowed
to burn before the eyes of the i
habitants. The library was totally destroyed. Louvain will never
recover from the effects of wanton destruction, but something is
being done for it, both in the
United States and in England.

here is being directed by Dr.
Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University. The
National Committee of the United
States for the Restoration of the
Louvain Library will collect the
mass of books that are offered by
the numerous colleges and univerThese

books, combined with those donated by England, will form the
nucleus of the library of the University of Louvain. The books
from both countries will be catalogued and presented together.
The splendid collection to be
presented by Johns Hopkins is
made up of over two hundred volumes of serial publications that
have been bound. Among these
are the American Chemical Journal, the American Journal of
Mathematics, the American Journal of Philology, Modern Language Notes and Studies of Historical and Political Science. Besides these, the Library Committee will endeavor to influence the
faculty to present some of their

After the nucleus of the Louvain library is formed, the list of
gifts given by the universities will
be used as a basis of appeal to
the general public to do its share
also.
The Library Committee, as it is
now composed, consists of President Frank Goodnow, chairman,
ex officio; Dr. Llewellyn Raney,
secretary, ex officio; Professors E.
B. Mathews, W. W. Willoughby,

The second of the Y. M. C. A.'s
series of lectures given with the
idea of helping undergraduates to
choose their life work was delivered by Mr. Eugene Levering, at
the lunch hour on Tuesday, March
4. Mr. Levering is the president
of the National Bank of Commerce
of Baltimore and one of the trustees of the University.
After speaking of the formation
of the world's first bank in Italy,
some time during the twelfth century, and of the gradual spreading of the institutions up through
Holland to England and over Europe, Mr. Levering spoke of the
three important kinds of banks
that were finally evolved and that
are at present in use. These three
kinds are: the savings bank, the
trust company and the commercial
bank.
The first savings bank was
formed about a hundred years ago
by a group of men who saw the
need of a bank especially adapted
to encourage the habit of saving.
The savings bank's great functions
are to help men by helping them
to save money and to supply long
term capital to business. The trust
company's major function, Mr.
Levering stated, is to develop industrial enterprises, such as the
railroads.
The commercial banks are divided into two classes: the national bank and the state bank.
There are many more state banks
than national banks; indeed, the
ratio is almost two to one. The
state banks are almost as well
managed now as the national
banks. This is brought about by
a method of state inspection corresponding to the Government inspection of national banks. The
function of the commercial bank
is seen when we consider the wonderful benefit the banks bestow on
business. A merchant, for instance, receives checks from all
parts of the country. Does he
send men around to all the banks
upon which the checks are drawn
to collect his money? Not at all.
What he does is simply to send all
his checks to his own bank, which
credits him with their amounts.
Then his bank, through the clearing-house, sends all the checks to
their proper banks. But the greatest benefit commercial banks bestow on business is to supply
short-term capital.

"Tiff" Williams Elected Toastmaster

A meeting of the senior class
was held on Thursday, March 6,
in the Mechanical Engineering
Building to discuss several important matters relating to the welfare of the class. In the first
place, there was the matter of
electing a toastmaster for the senior banquet, which will take place
some time next month. The earsplitting roar which greeted the
nomination of "Tiff" Williams
for this position showed, beyond
a doubt, that no other candidate
would have a chance against him;
and the recognized "funny man"
of the class was elected by acclamation. This hilarious• demonstration was but short-lived, however, for the announcement which
immediately followed — that the
four-dollar pledges for the banquet would have to be signed then
and there—cast a gloomy silence
over the whole class. But the
thought of the approaching "dry
season" would have soon reconciled most of the men to any expenditure for the joys of a single
convivial evening, had not President Chisholm added insult to injury by saying that a collection
would have to be made to pay dues
to the Student Council and for
various other matters. There was
a large crowd present, but unfortunately the treasurer was absent, and so lost a good chance
of getting the money.
Thomsen announced that the
Hullabaloo is coming on splendidly, and from present indications
will be a year-book worthy of the
class. He urged all men who have
not yet done so to turn in their
biographies.

Boxing And Wrestling Classes Started.

Wrestling and boxing classes at
Hopkins have brought out material which will well be able to represent the University in the intercollegiate meets. These two new
„sports have but recently been
started under the new plan for
universal athletic participation by
the undergraduate students.
The wrestling teams especially
are now considered among the
most important athletic groups in
the eastern colleges. Annual winter schedules with final championship bouts have brought the
sport of the mat to the foreground
in college athletics. Although boxing and wrestling have not sought
recognition as minor sports, yet
it is expected that if Hopkins can
develop teams which hold their
own in the collegiate leagues, the
Athletic Board will give its approval.
Instruction in these two sports
is compulsory for the Sophomores,
and classes are open for all other
men interested. G. Wagner and
J. Marcuse are the boxing instructors, while A. Hendricks and
T. Gould coach the men on the
various holds in wrestling.
The classes meet for instruction on the fourth floor of Gilman
Hall, where large floor space offers room for several mats and
rings. Showers on the same floor
are used by the men. It is expected that as soon as a few men
get into shape, exhibitions will be
held at noon, and even public
bouts may be given.
While the weather prevents the
opening of the spring football
practice, Coach Murphy is urging
the candidates to get into shape
by practice on the canvas or with
the gloves. Experience as athletic director in the army camps
has convinced the coach that
these two sports are among the
best ways to get hardened and
• into shape for the fall workouts.

Her Sacrifice.

I met a lady yesterday,
Who's face was wan, who's look
was sad;
Had you some boys in France? I
asked,
"Just one," she said, "my only
lad."
Has he returned? I asked. She said:
"No, sir, he'll not come back, he's
dead."
Where did he fall? I gently asked,
Your gallant lad, your only son,
At Chateau Thierry or St. Mihiel.
"No, sir," she said, "down near
Verdun."
And then she stopped and sadly
sighed,
I thought I fully understood,
"And, sir," she said, "his father, too,
Was killed down in the Argonne
Wood."

• Despite the fact that comparatively few men at the University
realize what the Hopkins Y. M.
C. A. stands for and what it is
doing this year (aside from staging free movies each week), this
vitally important organization has
been quite active. Perhaps the
most interesting and helpful work
with which the Y. M. C. A. has
been connected this winter is that
of teaching the blind soldiers at
Evergreen Junior.
These soldiers, as most students
know, are lai,;.4y overseas men,
whose eyesighi has been impaired
and who are temporarily established in barracks on the grounds
of Mrs. T. Harrison Garrett.
Some are totally blind, others have
a slight use of their sight, but
only a few of the latter have a
chance of recovery. They are receiving courses of instruction preparatory to entering a useful vocation, and it is in conducting
these courses that a number of
Hopkins men have been' helping.
The Hopkins"instructors," numbering a dozen in all, have been
divided into two squads, one for
Tuesday nights and the other for
Friday nights. The period of instruction is from 8 to 10 o'clock,
allowing one hour to be devoted to
the study of grammar and the
other to salesmanship. As there
are only a few soldiers taking this
advanced course, the work is a
personal one, and is especially appealing when one stops to consider
the sacrifice which they made.
They are very cheerful and willing
to learn, and deeply appreciate the
help which the University is thus
extending to them. Anyone who
may be interested in work of this
kind may obtain further information from Harold Mersereau,
Charles T. Leber or John Bartels.
